title: Mia Farrow speaks at UT Arlington Thursday
text:

Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Mia Farrow speaks at UT Arlington Thursday Robert Cadwallader, Star-Telegram 10:05 a.m. CDT October 8, 2015 NEW YORK, NY - APRIL 21: Samantha Power, Ronan Farrow and Mia Farrow attend TIME 100 Gala, TIME's 100 Most Influential People In The World on April 21, 2015 in New York City. (Photo: Larry Busacca / Getty Images) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
ARLINGTON -- Before she was Mia Farrow the actor, the humanitarian or the paparazzi red meat, she was a frightened, 9-year-old girl stricken with polio and tucked away in a medical ward away from her family and a raging epidemic of fear in the country. 
"None of us in that ward new which of us would die," said Farrow, who became one who beat the disease, but not, she hopes, its lingering effect on her young mind. 
"I know it made me aware of another world outside my very beautiful Beverly Hills childhood, a world of pain and suffering and fear. I came to know those things. Now what I would do about those things later in my life, I had no idea." 
Today, the 70-year-old, long-time Connecticut resident is known for an extensive film career, including Rosemary's Baby when she was 23, but increasingly for her humanitarian passion for shedding light on human rights abuses against families in conflict-torn countries.
